user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 8.13 is: A pointer should point to a const-qualified type whenever possible.

</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport:
```c
void UtAssert_DoTestSegmentReport(const char *SegmentName, const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters)
{
    char ReportBuffer[144];

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%-22s ABORT::%-4u  WARN::%-4u  FLOW::%-4u  DEBUG::%-4u  N/A::%-4u",
             "",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_ABORT],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_WARN],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FLOW],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_DEBUG],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_NA]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_INFO, ReportBuffer);

    snprintf(ReportBuffer, sizeof(ReportBuffer),
             "%02u %-20s TOTAL::%-4u  PASS::%-4u  FAIL::%-4u  MIR::%-4u  TSF::%-4u  TTF::%-4u",
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->TestSegmentCount, SegmentName, (unsigned int)TestCounters->TotalTestCases,
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_PASS],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_FAILURE],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_MIR],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TSF],
             (unsigned int)TestCounters->CaseCount[UTASSERT_CASETYPE_TTF]);

    UT_BSP_DoText(UTASSERT_CASETYPE_END, ReportBuffer);
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Most pointer uses in this function are already const-qualified: the parameters 'const char *SegmentName' and 'const UtAssert_TestCounter_t *TestCounters' are const as required by the rule. The usages of TestCounters and SegmentName inside snprintf are reads through const-qualified pointers, and the explicit casts to (unsigned int) are not pointer-related, so they do not pertain to Rule 8.13. The ReportBuffer array is a modifiable destination (written by snprintf), so its declaration as a non-const char array is appropriate and should not be flagged unless a called function incorrectly requires a non-const pointer. The two UT_BSP_DoText calls and the use of the string literal "" are flagged because they involve passing a character pointer to external APIs: these calls should be investigated to confirm the callee prototypes accept a pointer to const char (i.e. const char *) — if the callee instead declares a non-const pointer parameter, that would violate Rule 8.13. All other fragments in the function either already use const-qualified pointers or do not involve pointers and therefore do not need investigation under Rule 8.13.
